metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of ground truth measurements synchronizing with airborne PLMR mission in the Yingke oasis and Huazhaizi desert steppe on July 10, 2012
metadata.description:
On July 10, 2012, the airborne flight and ground observation was synchronously carried out in the PLMR quadrat of Yingke Oasis and the Huazhaizi Desert. PLMR (Polarimetric L-band Multibeam Radiometer) is a dual-polarized (H/V) L-band microwave radiometer with a center frequency of 1.413 GHz, a bandwidth of 24 MHz, and a resolution of 1 km (relative flight height of 3 km).The radiometer has 6 beams to observe synchronously, and the incident angles are ±7º，±21.5º，±38.5º, and the sensitivity is less than 1K. The flight observation mainly covers the artificial oasis eco-hydrological test area in the middle reaches. This ground-synchronized data set provides a basic ground dataset for developing and validating passive microwave remote sensing inversion soil moisture algorithms.
Quadrat and sampling strategy:
The observation area is located in the transition zone between the southern margin of Zhangye Oasis and Anyang beach desert, the west side of Zhang (Zhangye)-Da (Daman) highway. It is divided into two parts by the main canal of the Dragon Canal from North to South. The Southwest area is a desert quadrat with the size of 1 km×1 km. The desert is relatively homogeneous, so soil moisture of 5 points in the 1 km quadrat are collected (1 point of each corner and the center point, in the actual measurement process, several extra points can be measured along the road). The four corner points are 600 meters away from each other,except the diagonal direction. And the southwest corner point is Huazhaizi Desert Station, for the convenience of comparison with weather station data. On the northeast side, a large size quadrat of 6 km×1.6 km is selected for simultaneous observation of the oasis underlying surface.In order to obtain the brightness temperature comparison with the PLMR observation, the quadrat was chose based on the following factors :surface coverage representative, avoiding the residential and greenhouses, crossing the oasis farmland and part of the Southern desert, accessibility, and observation time(road consumption).
Taking the resolution of PLMR observations into consideration, in the synchronous observation, 11 sampling lines (East-West distribution) were collected with an interval of 160 meters from the East to the West. Each line from the North to the South was separated by 21 points with an interval of 80 meters. And 4 Hydraprobe Data Acquisition System (HDAS, Reference 2) were used to measure simultaneously.
Measurement contents:
About 230 points of the quadrat were collected, 2 observations were performed on each point, that is, 2 observations were performed on each sampling point of the film mulched corn field, 1 inside the film (marked as a in the data record), 1 outside the film (marked as b in the data record). Since the HDAS system useed the POGO portable soil sensor, the soil temperature, soil moisture (volumetric water content), loss tangent, soil electrical conductivity, soil complex dielectric real part and imaginary part were obtained by observation. No special simultaneous sampling of vegetation was carried out on the same day.
Data:
The data set includes two parts: soil moisture observation and vegetation observation. The former saves the data as a vector file, the spatial position is the position of each sampling point (WGS84+UTM 47N), and the measurement information of soil moisture is recorded in the attribute file.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary method for synchronizing ground measurements with remote sensing data in eco-hydrological studies based on hierarchical instrumentation, sparse network establishment, or superstation construction?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the main instruments used in airborne remote sensing missions in eco-hydrological studies?
Concept Completion.Answer: LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, L-band microwave radiometer

Concept Completion.Question: Where was the observational area focused during the eco-hydrological experiment in the Heihe River Basin?
What method is used to ensure the quality control of observational data collected in eco-hydrological experiments?

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that incorporates multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert area?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is the multiscale dataset from the HiWATER experiment, which includes data from eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, along with hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting multiscale observations for eco-hydrological studies?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. HiWATER addresses this by employing instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain comprehensive multiscale data.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the sampling strategy implemented in the oasis-desert ecotone for data collection?
Feature Specification.Answer: surface coverage representativeness, accessibility, time efficiency, 5 points within a 1 km area, 11 lines with 21 points each, 80 m intervals, membrane-covered and uncovered points

Quantification.Question: What was the resolution of the L-band microwave radiometer used in the data collection method?

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'ground synchronous observation' in the context of remote sensing data collection?
Definition.Answer: Ground synchronous observation refers to the process of conducting ground-based measurements that coincide with airborne or satellite remote sensing observations. This ensures that data from both sources can be accurately compared and correlated, providing a comprehensive understanding of the observed variables, such as soil moisture and vegetation dynamics.

Comparison.Question: How does the resolution and sensitivity of the PLMR radiometer compare to other instruments used in multiscale eco-hydrological observations, such as LiDAR or imaging spectrometers?
Comparison.Answer: The PLMR radiometer has a resolution of 1 km and a sensitivity of less than 1K. In comparison, other instruments like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers used in multiscale observations have different resolutions and capabilities. LiDAR provides hyper-resolution data and 3D surface models, while imaging spectrometers capture high-resolution spectral data. Each instrument offers unique data characteristics suited for specific observational needs in eco-hydrological studies.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of multiscale observations impact the development of soil moisture algorithms for passive microwave remote sensing compared to those used in other remote sensing modalities?
Comparison.Answer: Multiscale observation challenges impact the development of soil moisture algorithms for passive microwave remote sensing by requiring algorithms that can handle data across different resolutions and scales, which is often less of an issue for other remote sensing modalities like optical or thermal imaging. The development of these algorithms must consider the integration of coarse resolution data with finer-scale ground truth points, whereas other modalities might focus more on spectral or spatial resolution challenges. The availability of multiscale data is crucial for validation and refinement of these algorithms.

Interpretation.Question: How can the arrangement of instruments in hierarchically nested scales enhance the understanding of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes?
Interpretation.Answer: The arrangement of instruments in hierarchically nested scales allows for the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by providing detailed observations at different spatial scales. This setup helps in understanding interactions between the oasis and desert systems, as seen through the placement of a superstation within the oasis and various towers and stations in surrounding landscapes. Such a configuration facilitates the collection of diverse data that can be integrated to depict complex environmental interactions.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in collecting multiscale and multidisciplinary data in heterogeneous surfaces?
Interpretation.Answer: Collecting multiscale and multidisciplinary data on heterogeneous surfaces poses challenges due to the limited availability of comprehensive observations across various scales. Ensuring a consistent quality and integration of data from diverse sources like flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and airborne remote sensing requires careful calibration, processing, and validation. The need for synchronizing ground measurements with airborne missions further complicates the data collection process.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining multiscale observations in heterogeneous surfaces like oasis-desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, as noted in the background of the relevant papers. The complexity of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces necessitates a well-structured observation system, which can be difficult to implement due to the need for hierarchical and nested instrumentation scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to conduct multiple airborne remote sensing missions to cover areas like the oasis-desert system in Heihe Watershed?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The necessity of conducting multiple airborne remote sensing missions is to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes effectively. Instruments such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer are employed to obtain comprehensive data at different scales, which is crucial for understanding the interactions within the oasis-desert system.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might arise from using an L-band microwave radiometer for soil moisture measurement in eco-hydrological studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using an L-band microwave radiometer, such as the PLMR, can provide high-resolution soil moisture data, which is essential for developing and validating soil moisture retrieval algorithms in passive microwave remote sensing. This contributes to improving the understanding and modeling of eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces like oasis-desert systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop and validate soil moisture retrieval algorithms using passive microwave remote sensing in the context of the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The dataset aims to provide fundamental ground data for the development and validation of passive microwave remote sensing soil moisture retrieval algorithms. This approach is crucial for improving the accuracy and applicability of remote sensing techniques in capturing soil moisture dynamics in heterogeneous landscapes like the Heihe River Basin.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective of arranging instruments on hierarchically nested scales in eco-hydrological experiments like HiWATER?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by arranging instruments on hierarchically nested scales. This method allows for the collection of multiscale and multidisciplinary data, addressing the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental techniques are utilized to ensure the accurate collection of soil moisture data in heterogeneous eco-hydrological environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The Polarimetric L-band Multibeam Radiometer (PLMR) is used, which is a dual-polarization microwave radiometer, alongside the Hydraprobe Data Acquisition System (HDAS) for soil moisture measurements. The PLMR provides data at a resolution of 1 km, while the HDAS uses a portable soil sensor to capture soil temperature, moisture, and electrical properties at multiple points within the study area.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of airborne remote sensing technologies facilitate the collection of eco-hydrological data in the Heihe River Basin?
Enablement.Answer: Airborne remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer facilitate the collection of eco-hydrological data by conducting 12 missions to cover the area, enabling high-resolution and multi-angle observations that capture complex eco-hydrological processes and interactions in the basin.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that the availability of multiscale observations is limited in eco-hydrological studies, and how might this impact data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: The availability of multiscale observations is limited due to the complexity of capturing eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. This limitation impacts data collection methods by necessitating the use of hierarchically nested scales and a sparse network of instruments to capture the interactions between different landscapes, such as the oasis-desert system.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be expected that synchronical ground measurements are not always conducted for vegetation dynamics during data collection, and what implications does this have for datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Synchronical ground measurements for vegetation dynamics might not always be conducted due to logistical constraints, such as time and accessibility issues. This has implications for datasets as it may lead to gaps in data, affecting the comprehensiveness and accuracy of modeling vegetation processes in relation to eco-hydrological dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the current data collection methods in capturing the multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and addressing the challenge of poor multiscale observations in oasis-desert areas?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods used in the HiWATER experiment are designed to be highly effective in capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. They employ a hierarchically nested instrumentation approach, including a sparse network of observation stations, airborne remote sensing missions, and a detailed ground measurement framework. These methods help to address the challenge of poor multiscale observations by providing a comprehensive dataset that is carefully quality controlled.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes.
Assertion.Answer: The primary challenge in obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes is the poor availability of such data. The experiment addresses this by deploying a sparse network of instruments in hierarchically nested scales, conducting multiple airborne remote sensing missions, and implementing intensive observations at different landscape scales, such as oasis-desert interactions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the primary challenges faced in obtaining multiscale observations in the field of eco-hydrological processes and suggest potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The primary challenge in obtaining multiscale observations is the poor availability of such data. To address this, the HiWATER experiment employed a hierarchical instrumentation approach, involving intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations with a sparse network of instruments. Implementing a multiscale dataset system, like the one used in HiWATER, which includes various remote sensing and ground-based measurement techniques, can provide a comprehensive solution.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that can be used for validating soil moisture retrieval algorithms in oasis-desert systems and describe their characteristics.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential dataset for validating soil moisture retrieval algorithms is the one obtained from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER). This dataset includes ground measurements of soil moisture in different landscapes, such as sandy desert, desert pavement, and oasis areas. The dataset is characterized by its multiscale and multidisciplinary nature, containing flux observations, eco-hydrological sensor data, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data. It is available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.
